Award.AbstractNarration:
Doctoral Dissertation Research:
Making Space for Mexican Wolves: Technology, Knowledge and Conservation Politics

Abstract

The use of geospatial technologies has proliferated in efforts to reintroduce and conserve wildlife. Radio and GPS collars are being used to track wildlife, in the hopes that removing nuisance animals will defuse conflicts between wildlife and land users and lead to increased tolerance for endangered species. Problems persist, nevertheless, as these new technologies are adopted, and adapted, and learned through out land management agencies and the general public. Notably, captive-bred Mexican wolves (Canis lupus baileyi) have been reintroduced to the Apache, Sitgreaves and Gila National Forests in Arizona and New Mexico. The project, which involves extensive use of collaring, tracking, and mapping technologies, has not met its goal of 102 wolves and 18 breeding pairs in the wild, nor has consensus been achieved among key actors. Illegal shootings and removals of nuisance wolves have likely contributed to stagnated population growth. This research examines the Mexican Wolf Reintroduction Project to answer three primary questions:
1. How has geospatial technology influenced the governance of Mexican wolves and the construction of a Mexican wolf territory?
2. How has the governance of Mexican wolves and the construction of a wolf territory impacted land use in the Blue Range Wolf Recovery Area?
3. How is spatialized knowledge constructed by diverse publics and represented in particular Mexican wolf policy agendas?
GIS analysis will be combined with a qualitative study of the processes influencing the management of wolves and the creation of spatial knowledge. The qualitative study will consist of interviews, participant observation with the Mexican wolf field team, and content analysis of archival documents. The GIS analysis will compare conceptual maps drawn by research participants with wolf location data to produce a map that shows priority areas for reducing people-wolf conflicts.
The research will advance understandings of the role of geospatial technologies in conservation. Results will inform policies to successfully conserve Mexican wolves and reduce people-wolf conflicts, contribute technical resources to the analysis of Mexican wolf distribution and provide an avenue for the incorporation of community perspectives in Mexican wolf management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of radio and GPS collars and Geographic Information Systems Technology is now routine in wildlife conservation. While generally viewed as tools to gather information that will advance wildlife science and  improve conservation, tracking and mapping technologies are also used to control animals. The wider implications of this technology have yet to be carefully considered, however. Specifically, mapping and tracking wild animals has implications both for how members of the public think about wildlife, as well as how managers actually conduct conservation. This research examined the use of radio collars and geospatial technology to monitor and control wolves in the Mexican Wolf reintroduction project taking place in Arizona and New Mexico. The study asked: how does tracking and mapping technology influence the knowledge and practice of Mexican wolf conservation? How, if at all, do these technologies (including radio collars, digital mapping, and related innovations) change the way managers work and the way local people relate to the question of wolf reintroduction, to authorities, and to one another? Do these technologies increase or decrease conflicts surrounding wildlife?

The research included two components: 1) a qualitative study of the social processes that influence the governance of Mexican wolf reintroduction and 2) a GIS-based analysis of the distribution of wolves and human-wolf conflicts.  The researcher conducted interviews with project participants, including federal, state and local government agency officials, Mexican wolf field team personnel, land users, local residents and anti- and pro-wolf advocates. Policy and planning documents and program reports were analyzed. In addition, the researcher engaged in participant observation with the wolf field team, to gain insights into the daily activities of wolf management. The GIS-based study involved analysis of hand-drawn maps obtained through a participatory mapping exercise, as well as the collection of spatial data on Mexican wolf home ranges and environmental and social variables in the Blue Range Wolf Recovery Area.

The results suggest that one of the key underlying assumptions of the reintroduction program - that removing “problem” wolves from the range will reduce cattle depredations and also minimize the occurrence of illegal shootings of wolves – may be unfounded. Cattle depredations have not decreased, illegal shootings continue to occur, and opposition to Mexican wolves by local communities and land users has not abated (Figure 1).

In addition, the results suggest that radio collars tend to individualize specific wolves, making them seem “domesticated” in the minds of some parts of the observing public. This leads to disappointment for some observers, by failing to satisfy the desire for “wild” wolves in our midst, and further de-legitimizing their claim to a place on the land in the eyes of opponents of their reintroduction.

Two other desires, amongst both managers and the public, were also demonstrated to conflict. The need to know about wolves, whether to monitor them for problem behavior, control their movements, or to celebrate their role in nature, was observed to conflict with competing desires for the persistence of animals whose presence is beyond human design and control. Collaring wolves, however, also allows for a high level of care and concern for individualized wolves and wolf packs. This might, over the long term, help to shift attitudes to Mexican wolves, reduce the level of opposition to their presence and foster the implementation of more creative and effective strategies to achieve the coexistence of wolves and people in a shared territory.
